Hi (vice),

I hope you’re doing well! My name is Ali, and I run Snowline Nature Tours here in Pakistan. I’m reaching out because I believe Pakistan has so much to offer for your next documentary project, and I’d love to help make that happen.

Pakistan is a treasure trove of stories and stunning landscapes waiting to be captured. Imagine filming the Karakoram Range's towering peaks, the Hunza lush green valleys, and the bustling, colorful markets in our historic cities. I think you’d find so much diversity and beauty here fascinating.

Here’s how we can help you get the most out of your documentary adventure:

Easy Transportation: We’ve covered all your travel needs so you can focus on filming, not logistics.
Comfortable Stays: Whether you prefer cozy mountain lodges or chic city hotels, we’ll set you up with accommodations that suit your style.
Custom Itineraries: Have specific locations or themes in mind? We’ll tailor the trip to meet your exact needs.
Local Insights: Our experienced guides know the best spots and hidden gems, ensuring your documentary stands out
Cultural Connections: We’ll introduce you to local communities, allowing you to capture their traditions and everyday life up close.
Unique Stories: We provide unique stories and opportunities for YouTubers, Instagrammers, and TikTokers.
Shooting Anywhere: We have the license to shoot anywhere in Pakistan, allowing you to film without any worries.
Pakistan is still relatively under-explored in the documentary world, which means there are countless fresh and unique stories to tell. I would be thrilled to assist you in uncovering those stories.

If this sounds like something you’d be interested in, let’s chat! Reach out with questions or ideas you have. I’m excited about the possibility of working together and can’t wait to show you the wonders of Pakistan.

I am looking forward to hearing from you soon!

Warm regards,
Ali
Owner, Snowline Nature Tours

First, we have to stop calling these important people of the forest pygmies because it is a very disrespectful way to refer to someone as such. In the Ituri forest of Zaire are a small statured people called Bambuti which consist of two groups the Imbuti and the Efe. They are the earliest links to humankind and the first known human type as what we know today as homo sapiens that emerged in East Africa some 250 to 350 thousand years ago who later populated the rest of the world in places like India, Southeast Asia and the South Pacific as the aboriginal people of these locations. The 4.5-million-year-old fossil found in Ethiopia commonly known as Lucy (Dekenesh) was a small stature Hominid woman of the so- called pigmy type. This is not here say as it is buttressed, documented, verified and backed up by the anthropological and bimolecular scientific data. In addition, they are also located in Uganda called the Batwa and South Africa in the Kalahari called the San. This name "Pigmy" emerged during the early 19th century and perhaps earlier by British traveler John Barrow who travels Into the Interior of Southern Africa (1806). These groups of people have names and should be referred by their names or as small statured people in description but not some derogatory name to suit the Western mentality. It is obvious the narrator is reading from a script and has done no meaningful research of his own as he continues to be disrespectful by using the term pygmies. These groups thrive as hunter and gatherers who practice the purist form of what we know as communisms or shall I say egalitarianism. They have fought no wars, nor have they imposed themselves on any one or nations throughout their existence. They practice a system of sharing and caring that has sustained themselves for many thousands of years but have been interrupted and infringed on by Arab slavery, colonialism, and other neighboring countries (forced migration and industrialism) in the past several hundred years. These small statured people like the Bambuti (Mbuti & Efe) were first observed by the Kemetians (Egyptians) during an exhibition to find the source of the Nile River in the fourth dynasty. In the tomb of Pharaoh Nefrikare is preserved (coffin text) a report from his commander Herkouf, who entered a great forest to the West of the Mountain of the Moon and discovered there a people of the trees a tiny people who sing and dance to their God, a dance such as had never been seen before. Nefrikare sent a reply ordering Herkouf to bring one of these dancers of God back with him, giving explicit instructions as to how he should be treated and cared for so that no harm would come to him. As a consequence, these small statured people such as the Baka and the Bambuti people of the forest were written in the annuals of Egyptian (Kemet) history as they became a part of Egyptian life and ultimately had important position in the society such as blacksmiths and jewelers. The Ankh is a symbol that represent eternal life and the tittle or name given to them was "Ankhi" The living one, as they rose to prominence.  We also have the ancient Egyptian deity Bes (so-called pigmy) who was worshipped as a protector of households and, in particular, of mothers, children, and childbirth. Bes later came to be regarded as the defender of everything good and the enemy of all that is bad. So, when we refer to these small stature people of the forest, we must refer to them by their group names and also as very important people to whom we owe respect and homage to.

I spent 2 weeks deep in the Rainforest with a tribe of people that lived in it. They hunted and gathered stuff from the Forrest every day. They also grew tomatoes and peppers and some leafy plants that they’d grind up and mix with chili to eat in the morning. But about 80% of that village also grew their own weed. They would take bones from animals they’d killed and boiled all the flesh off before cooking them over the fire so they dry out before they crush them and mix urine and charcoal together as a fertilizer. The plants would get 9-12 feet tall and produced some of the most incredible marijuana there is on the planet. Orange, purple, red, yellow colors all over the buds. The smell was so strong when you’re 2 miles down wind you can still smell it. When they go to harvest hundreds of pounds they slash the plants down and hang them upside down to dry. Then sold it for (if I did the math right) 10lbs would get them about $260 American. These tribes get so ripped off by the other tribes and other African

Great documentary! (However!) The community chief was "shocked" to hear that THE INTERVIEWERS HAD BROKEN INTO A  MINE. By the looks of everyone's faces and their body language, they were very uncomfortable. The micro-expressions  and the body language of the main interviewer emitted guilt and shame. The indigenous people in the area have absolutely no reason to lie. They are extremely poverty stricken, yet they are far from stupid. Reminds me of how the Europeans entered into Africa in the 1500's, and my ancestors (from West Africa  and  the Congo) were so welcoming and hospitable to their peril. The Europeans were not there to trade; they were there to steal our resources, kidnap us and make us their slaves to build their wealth while they colonize our lands. Although this video is very educational and enlightening, it is somewhat disappointing  to see that some things never change.

This video touches on the fact past generations considered some West Africans sub-human. Maybe they weren't wrong.

Now hear me out! Genetic research has proven Present-day sub-Saharan Africans trace up to 19% of their genetic ancestry to an extinct archaic hominid species (Homo erectus or Homo habilis) that is NOT found in the DNA of present-day non-Africans

In 2011 DNA from three groups (Biaka Pygmies, San, and Mandinka) were tested and shown to come from a now-extinct species that broke away from the modern human lineage over 700,000 years ago.

In 2012 another study tested three sub-Saharan African populations (Pygmies, Hadza, and Sandwe) and it was again found that the ancestors of modern African bred with different species of hominins, not found in the DNA of non-Africans

I think it's time the world acknowledge the difficult truths and that some problems can no longer be be blamed on exploitation, culture differences, or the oppression of past generations. I'm all for leaving Africa to the Africans but just think what that would look like.....

Yes! I think of all the folks that would be clutching their pearls about teaching women to sell drugs instead of something else, but when kids get through school, even uni, and can’t find work back home, why not? It’s not the same as the drug dealers an American would think about…but being picked up off the street for sex is dangerous everywhere. Working the fields for veg to sell in the market is dangerous with rebel groups around, even. I am glad they’ve found a way to better their lives, connect to other women, and almost have a sort of support group where men and women smoke together and just…forget that life is hard for a bit. She’s a businesswoman, mentor, and therapist, at the very least. Respect to her - and all the women choosing ganja over prostitution in a difficult place!

Others like the Mbuti as well, who are making the best of an awful situation with weed, also get all my respect. Treated like subhumans, driven from their home, forced to change their way of life…but they can at least bring in a little money with weed, plus use it as natural medicine (and I appreciate their rule to only take leaves from their own plants or the medication doesn’t work, talk about good neighbors). We are all humans. We should be treated as humans. I hope, for the sake of them, the women in Goma, everyone really, that eastern Congo sees a lasting peace that doesn’t involve the west/China/Russia making a grab for resources in return for helping to rebuild and modernize infrastructure.

(oops I typed too much! but to your point, again, 1000% yes, she is an angel on earth for helping these struggling women avoid prostitution.)

I meant no offense towards anyone, under educated or otherwise. I was making general point of advice, not about you specifically. But, I'm very happy to discuss your specific situation.
Full disclosure and with some regrets, I have little more than a 55 year old high school education and have a degree in the hard knocks of life.
Since you're making this about your own personal life. Who are you?
1: A teenager preparing for the 9th grade
2: A school dropout, which never looks good on job applications, while competing against college grads. From most employers' POV, that indicates being a rebel, undisciplined, a know-it all attitude, lack of initiative, ... That doesn't even address the applicant's appearance at the interview, where one is judged the harshest.
3: Perhaps you're an adult, married with children, working 2 minimum wage jobs to support yourselves? Splitting the rent in a shared apartment? Been there, done with that. Just made my final mortgage payment on my home, 100% free of debt and finally able to live the free life @ 72. I speak from >1/2 century worth life's struggles, only to become a hermit.
Yes, we have our own brains, IF we have the discipline to seek out sufficient knowledge to achieve our goals.
Even while retired, I'm still a student of Youtube U, learning C++, MIDI, Kicad PCB design, electronics, and I'm just finishing the development of a 100% unique laser synthesizer for creating abstract imagery synchronized to music... for fun, not profit.
"No brag, just fact."
Enough about myself,.
Do you have legit goals, including solid plans for achieving them or only dreams? 'Possible' indicates 'against all odds', not highly probable. It is your own life to gamble with those odds. But, it is irresponsible to advocate that others will be happy and prosperous with only an 8th grade education.
The point of my comment is that we live, work, and socialize (or not) within a rapidly changing competitive global economy, which requires higher education in science, math, physics, software engineering, A. I., EVs, CAD/CAM, medicine, genetic engineering,..
Those are the same skills that have made Bezos, Musk, Gates, and many others billionaires (while exploiting the undereducated).
Think about it. I'd love to hear your deeper thoughts for achieving your own version of success, which constantly changes with life, conditions, and maturity. I hope you're prepared for those rollercoaster rides of ups and downs. They will happen, whether you're prepared or not.

At 27mins in the UN man fails to mention how the UN presence enables corrupt government officials to sell off the land to countries such as China and Canada who mine and export the countries natural mineral resources. A few years ago I visited Kinshasa in the Democratic republic of Congo – DRC while there I saw so so many UN vehicles around seemingly doing noting noteworthy allowing so called legal mining. One day we took a trip out as I wanted to visit the national park an area I was told was like the ‘Garden of Eden. On our way we went to the village of a friend and past a small settlement of so called Pigmy people.  We crossed a huge road as wide as a six lane wide motorway was being cut out of the red earth, as far as the eye could see, trees and plants devastated - the sight was unbelievable. It was being dug out by ginormous digging machines to allow plant and processing machinery to be able to mine and export the mineral resources on a vast scale. The image at 37mins in is real and sadly can be seen in many African countries. It's crazy the amount of weed videos this guy makes and he says "It's a male plant, it has seeds", male plants do not have seeds my guy, they have pollen pods only. Male plants do not have seeds, male plants cannot be fertilized to have seeds.

Hermaphrodite plants and female plants can have seeds, male plants cannot have seeds.

As a Kenyan, I've always found it interesting to listen to the way the Congolese speak Swahili in their own dialect. Naturally, I'm more familiar with Swahili spoken in the Anglophone countries in Eastern Africa such as Tanzania for example(even though there's still some slight differences) but with a Francophone country such as The DRC it sounds a lot different. I can still pick out a bunch of the words they say but I really have to make a conscious effort to listen closely so that I can have an idea of the context.

I've known quite a few Congolese folks over the years here in Nairobi & I really hope things can get better for their nation in the near future. It sucks seeing a country so rich in resources essentially being looted for generations while most of its population stays living in abject poverty.

Starving is a punishment.  I found myself unemployed and risking homelessness....I looked around, and many people were throwing the leaves, stems, seeds, and pollen away as "scrap".   I bought butter.   I sifted the pollen; and cooked the scrap in butter, and made cookies. As I got more and more customers, more and more people brought me their discards.  For a few years, I managed to keep myself housed and fed that way.  When marijuana became LEGAL most of us could no longer earn money that way.  It was strange.  I wandered the South California selling snickerdoodles, pumpkin muffins, brownies, etc.  (changed by week)  We are no so very unlike, are we?
